title: Authentic, unapologetic, underappreciated: why Motorhead still matter
text:
NME readers once voted Motorhead "the best worst band in the world"; a few years later they were national treasures. To mark the release of a major retrospective, Ian Winwood remembers the pulverising power of Britain's purest rock band

The first time I interviewed Lemmy was in the bar of a London hotel in 1995. Drinking Jim Beam and Coke with a stoic determination, he was funny and kind. This came as a relief as I was breaking one of music journalism’s cardinal rules – never meet your heroes.

I was 10 years old when I first heard Motorhead, a three-minute earthquake from the radio that upended my life. The man responsible for this tumult seemed pleased to hear of it, and gave me an evening of his time.

At the bar he fell into a brief conversation with a well-dressed couple who asked what he did for a living. On learning that he was the bandleader with Motorhead, far too casually one of them said, “Oh, I didn’t know you were still going.” Lemmy appeared chastened – in truth, he looked hurt – and proceeded to give the disinterested pair a forensic account of the group’s recent past as well as a detailed itinerary of their immediate future.
